title: 103_s2479
content: The "United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994" promotes the construction and operation of US flag cruise vessels in the country. It also amends the Act to facilitate coastwise transportation of passengers. The "United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994" requires vessels in coastwise trade to be owned by US citizens, meet specific requirements, and have proper documentation. The "United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994" exempts cruise vessels under an 18-month demise charter to operate in coastwise trade for up to 6 months after the charter ends with approval from the Secretary. There is also an exception for vessels to be reflagged. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 exempts certain cruise vessels from specific regulations if they meet age and documentation criteria and the owner has a contract for a new vessel's construction in the US. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 exempts cruise vessels with a berth capacity of at least 80 percent of another vessel from certain regulations. The authority to operate expires 18 months after receiving a coastwise endorsement unless construction on a new vessel has begun. The Secretary of Transportation can extend this period. The Secretary of Transportation can extend the 18-month period for operating a cruise vessel in coastwise trade for an additional 6 months for good cause. A person owning or chartering a cruise vessel under a coastwise endorsement cannot operate between certain ports or the islands of Hawaii. Violators may face a civil penalty of $1,000 per passenger transported in violation. In violation, a vessel operated knowingly may be seized and forfeited to the United States Government. A person required to enter a construction contract for a cruise vessel may be disqualified from coastwise trade if construction milestones are not met. Coastwise trade includes transportation. The term 'coastwise trade' covers passenger transportation within the United States or via a foreign port. A 'cruise vessel' is a large ship with accommodations for at least 200 passengers, excluding ferries. A 'related person' includes holding companies, subsidiaries, affiliates, officers, directors, or agents of a person. SEC. 4. CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS. Section 3309 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to deem certain vessels compliant with specific regulations and requirements for inspection and certification. Vessels meeting specified criteria are eligible for a certificate of inspection and authorization to engage in coastwise trade. The Act of June 19, 1886, allows for the abolition of certain fees for official services to American vessels and amends laws related to shipping commissioners, seamen, and vessel owners. SEC. 5 amends the Shipping Act, 1916 regarding citizenship for vessel operation in passenger transport. SEC. 6 amends Title XI of the Merchant Marine Act, 1936. SEC. 6 amends Title XI of the Merchant Marine Act, 1936 by updating language related to passenger and cargo. SEC. 7 addresses permits for vessels entering units of the National Park System. The Secretary of the Interior may only permit vessels to operate in National Park System units based on priority: first, vessels documented in the US or with rights under the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act; second, foreign vessels already permitted to operate in the unit. The Secretary of the Interior can revoke permission for foreign-documented vessels to operate in National Park System units if a request is made to operate a US-documented vessel and permits are limited. The Secretary cannot revoke permission for those holding visitor services rights. Any person with revoked or not renewed permission to provide visitor services in a National Park System unit has the right of first refusal for available permits when conditions change. The right is limited to the number of permits revoked or not renewed.
